title: Instagram Reels can be 3 minutes long now + Instagram profile grids are going to feature rectangles instead of squares
summary:
- Instagram is changing profile grids from squares to rectangles starting this weekend.
- This decision was explained by CEO Adam Mosseri as necessary due to more vertical photos and videos being uploaded.
- Users may experience some transitional issues, but the change aims to enhance content display.
- The new grid format follows a limited test conducted in August 2024.
- Instagram is introducing a feature to view videos liked by friends in the Reels feed.
- The maximum length for Reels has been increased to 3 minutes from the previous 90 seconds.
- This update was influenced by user feedback suggesting the previous limit was too short.
- This marks a notable shift from prior statements about maintaining the platform's core identity and avoiding long-form content.
- The option to upload 1.5-minute Reels was introduced over two years ago, and longer durations are still being tested.

sources.title: Instagram profile grids are going to feature rectangles instead of squares
Instagram Reels can be 3 minutes long now

title: Once high-flying proptech startups Divvy Homes and EasyKnock are the latest to struggle
summary:
- Many proptech startups are struggling due to a decline in investments, dropping from $11.1 billion in 2021 to $3.7 billion in 2023.
- Divvy Homes is being acquired by Maymont Homes, while EasyKnock has abruptly shut down amidst lawsuits and regulatory actions.
- Divvy raised over $700 million from investors but faced challenges with high interest rates affecting its business model.
- EasyKnock faced allegations of deceptive practices and financial struggles, leading to its insolvency by the time of shutdown.
- The real estate fintech sector may continue to face similar challenges in 2025 due to high interest rates and lack of funding.

sources.title: Once high-flying proptech startups Divvy Homes and EasyKnock are the latest to struggle

title: Whitney Wolfe Herd Reclaims CEO Role at Bumble Amid Challenges
summary:
- Whitney Wolfe Herd will return as CEO of Bumble in mid-March 2025.
- She succeeds Lidiane Jones, who resigned for personal reasons.
- Bumble's Q3 2024 revenue decreased to $274 million, despite a rise in paying users to 4.3 million.
- The dating app sector faces issues like declining user engagement and increased scam concerns.
- Ann Mather will be appointed chair of the board of directors alongside Wolfe Herd's return.

sources.title: Bumble founder Whitney Wolfe Herd to reclaim CEO position in March
Bumble founder Whitney Wolfe Herd returns as CEO amid a dating app decline
Bumble’s founder will return as CEO in March

title: US warns of risks in Microsoft’s $13b OpenAI investment + Google inks a Gemini AI chatbot deal with the Associated Press
summary:
- Google announced a deal with the Associated Press (AP) to provide real-time news updates through its Gemini AI chatbot.
- AP will deliver a feed of information to enhance user results in the Gemini app, marking Google's first deal with a news publisher.
- Financial terms of the agreement were not disclosed, and it remains unclear how Google will present AP's content or credit the organization.
- AP has a history of seeking to diversify revenue streams, including a recent deal with OpenAI.
- Concerns have been raised about AI companies using news media content without permission, impacting revenue for traditional news outlets.
- The AP faces significant revenue loss from newspaper customers while trying to adapt to the evolving media landscape.

- The FTC has raised concerns about the power of major tech firms in AI, including Microsoft, Amazon, and Google.
- A report dated January 16 highlights risks with partnerships between big tech and AI startups, such as data advantages and resource consolidation.
- Specific examples include Microsoft's $13 billion investment in OpenAI and partnerships by Amazon and Google with Anthropic.
- Concerns include lock-in effects limiting startups and exclusive AI talent access.
- Criticism was directed at circular spending practices benefiting tech companies' products.
- An ongoing FTC investigation could inform future antitrust actions to ensure fair competition in AI.

sources.title: Google inks a Gemini AI chatbot deal with the Associated Press
US warns of risks in Microsoft’s $13b OpenAI investment

title: China Tightens Export Restrictions and Investigates US Chip Subsidies
summary:
* China launches an investigation into US subsidies for semiconductor companies.
* The investigation targets the impact of US subsidies on Chinese firms and global semiconductor markets.
* New export restrictions have been imposed, affecting key materials for semiconductor manufacturing.
* Apple's supply chain is likely to be impacted by these changes.
* These actions reflect escalating trade tensions between China and the US.

title: GoTo CEO unfazed by VinFast’s Indonesia entry
summary:
- GoTo CEO Patrick Walujo expresses confidence despite VinFast's entry into Indonesia's transportation market.
- Walujo differentiates Gojek's ride-hailing model from VinFast's automotive manufacturing focus.
- VinFast recently launched its electric taxi service in Indonesia, marking its second international venture.
- The electric vehicle market in Indonesia is becoming increasingly competitive with numerous options available.
- GoTo has shifted its focus back to Indonesia and Singapore after withdrawing from Vietnam, but still struggles for profitability.
- Walujo has committed to continue as CEO for another five years but is open to succession in the future if necessary.

title: TikTok's Potential US Operations Halt Amid Regulatory Uncertainty
summary:
- TikTok announced a potential halt of US operations starting January 19.
- This decision follows the Supreme Court upholding a law that may ban the platform.
- Over 170 million US users could be impacted by the ban.
- TikTok may be removed from US app stores unless the Biden administration provides assurance against a ban.
- The Supreme Court ruling mandates ByteDance to sell TikTok by January 19 to avoid a ban.
- The Biden administration is leaving TikTok's fate to the incoming Trump administration, which is negotiating a resolution.
- The White House Press Secretary indicated TikTok should remain available under ownership that addresses national security concerns.
- TikTok warns it will be forced to go dark if no assurance is received from the Biden administration by January 19.

sources.title: TikTok may halt US operations amid regulatory uncertainty
TikTok says it will go dark Sunday unless Biden offers ‘definitive statement’

title: Honor CEO George Zhao resigns ahead of IPO
summary:
- George Zhao announced his resignation as CEO of Honor on January 17 for personal and health reasons.
- Jian Li will succeed Zhao as CEO, having four years of experience in senior management at Honor.
- Zhao's resignation comes as Honor looks to finalize its IPO announced in 2023.
- Honor became independent from Huawei in 2020 and is focusing on global expansion and high-end smartphone development, including foldable models.

title: Samsung ties executive bonuses to stock performance
summary:
- Samsung Electronics will start linking executive bonuses to stock performance from January 2025.
- The stock-based bonus will comprise 50% to 100% of the annual bonus, depending on seniority.
- Executives will be prohibited from selling shares for one to two years.
- This change comes as Samsung competes in the semiconductor market and faces challenges from SK Hynix in AI memory chip production.
- The bonus system will adjust based on market performance; a drop in stock price means fewer shares for executives.
- There are plans to extend this program to non-executive employees by 2026, with voluntary participation and no market performance link.

sources.title: Samsung ties executive bonuses to stock performance

summary:
- WeChat launched a new gift-giving feature on January 17.
- Users can send gifts via chat or by searching for "gifts" in the app.
- The feature is available for most WeChat Mini Program products, excluding jewelry and education items.
- Eligible products must not exceed an original price of 10,000 yuan (around $1,365).
- Users can select a product, confirm payment, and choose a recipient; the recipient can exchange the gift for another of equal value before delivery.

title: TikTok CEO praises Trump for support amid looming ban + Biden passes TikTok ban enforcement to Trump administration
summary:

- The Supreme Court upheld legislation requiring ByteDance, TikTok's parent company, to divest ownership due to national security concerns.
- Enforcement details are unclear as Trump is set to take office before the ban's implementation.
- Biden's administration has been hesitant to impose penalties for non-compliance with the ban.
- Trump, who previously supported a TikTok ban, is uncertain about his approach this time.
- Reports indicate TikTok's future operations may face temporary shutdowns, though no official plans are announced.
- TikTok CEO expresses gratitude towards Trump for his support during a potential U.S. ban.

summary:
- The US government’s $52 billion Chips and Science Act aims to revitalize the semiconductor industry.
- Oversight will transition from the Biden administration to Donald Trump’s team on Jan. 20.
- The Biden administration allocated $39 billion to the program, leading to over $400 billion in private investments.
- There are 20 finalized agreements and 14 preliminary deals, but challenges remain in the semiconductor sector.
- TSMC has started production in Phoenix; advanced manufacturing will follow.
- Intel is experiencing delays and leadership changes, while Samsung has reduced its Texas investment.

summary:
- Donald Trump announced the launch of a new meme coin on his social media accounts just before his inauguration.
- Initial reactions included skepticism, with concerns over the legitimacy of the launch and funding sources from overseas exchanges Binance and Gate.
- The project is linked to the same team behind Trump’s previous NFT collections and has been confirmed by sources close to Trump’s family.
- Trump has a history of engaging with cryptocurrency, including launching NFT collections and planning an executive order on cryptocurrencies post-inauguration.

title: DOJ confirms arrested US Army soldier is linked to AT&T and Verizon hacks
summary:
- U.S. Army soldier Cameron John Wagenius was arrested on December 20, 2024, for transferring confidential phone records from AT&T and Verizon.
- The case is linked to previously indicted hackers who stole data from the cloud computing company Snowflake.
- The breaches affected many companies, with AT&T reporting that nearly all its customer call records were compromised.
- Wagenius claimed access to call logs of prominent figures and threatened to leak stolen files unless demands were met.
- He is currently in custody in Washington state, having been ordered detained on January 8, 2025.

sources.title: DOJ confirms arrested US Army soldier is linked to AT&T and Verizon hacks

title: US Supreme Court Upholds TikTok Ban Amid National Security Concerns
summary:
- The US Supreme Court upheld a law that could ban TikTok by January 19 unless its parent company, ByteDance, divests ownership.
- Concerns arise over ByteDance potentially sharing user data with China, affecting 170 million American users.
- The ban is linked to fears that Chinese AI could influence US public opinion using TikTok data.
- President Biden chose not to enforce the ban, leaving the decision to President-elect Trump.
- There is bipartisan conflict in Congress about whether TikTok should be allowed to continue operating in the US.
- The ruling emphasizes growing concerns regarding data privacy and national security in the digital age.

title: SpaceX Starship Rocket Explodes During Test Flight, Causing Flight Delays
summary:
- The SpaceX Starship explosion created a colorful debris display, resembling a meteor shower.
- The explosion occurred 8.5 minutes after the launch, during a test of a redesigned propulsion system.
- Flights from Miami and Fort Lauderdale were delayed by up to 45 minutes as the FAA diverted planes around the debris field.
- The launch took place at 5:38 p.m. EST (2238 GMT), and contact was lost shortly after liftoff.
- SpaceX indicated the explosion might have been due to a fire in the ship’s rear section.
- Initial assessments show debris fell within a designated hazard area, reducing potential risks.
- The FAA temporarily slowed plane operations in the area but has since returned to normal.

sources.title: SpaceX’s fiery Starship explosion put on a fantastic show but delayed and diverted flights
Elon Musk’s Starship rocket explodes during SpaceX flight test

title: Reliance’s Jio posts 26% profit growth in Q3 FY25
summary:
- Jio Platforms recorded a 26% year-on-year net profit growth in Q3 FY25, totaling 6,861 crore rupees (approx. US$798 million).
- Revenue from operations increased by 19.2% year-on-year to 33,074 crore rupees (approx. US$3.8 billion).
- Average revenue per user (ARPU) rose to 203.3 rupees (approx. US$2.3), up from 181.7 rupees (approx. US$2.1) last year.
- Subscriber base grew by 2.4% year-on-year to 482 million, with 3.3 million new subscribers added this quarter.
- Jio has over 170 million 5G customers, representing 40% of its total wireless traffic.

title: With full speed ahead on AI investment, does ROI matter?
summary:
- The projected spending on AI is expected to reach $1 trillion in the coming years.
- Companies need to balance between investment and the economic value generated, especially in chip production. 
- Businesses are categorized into three types: Big Tech, supply chain companies, and applied AI businesses, each having different ROI considerations.
- Big Tech can afford to invest heavily without immediate ROI pressure due to their overall solid financial performance.
- Supply chain companies must overinvest in capacity to meet demand despite the risks of overestimating.
- Applied AI companies focus on measured investments with ROI targets, emphasizing strategic spending based on proven progress.
- Historical context is provided, comparing current AI investment trends to the dot-com boom, suggesting potential for both significant risk and reward.

sources.title: With full speed ahead on AI investment, does ROI matter?

title: 3 big predictions for AI in financial services in 2025
summary:
- By 2025, AI will enhance personalized experiences in financial services rather than replacing human roles.
- Collaborative AI will streamline processes, leading to faster and simpler customer interactions.
- Financial service providers will focus on niche solutions tailored for specific customer segments, moving away from one-size-fits-all approaches.
- Success will hinge on leveraging AI to bundle services that address unique customer needs, creating seamless experiences.

sources.title: 3 big predictions for AI in financial services in 2025

title: President Biden’s new executive order aims to bolster national security
summary:
- President Joe Biden issued an executive order on Thursday to strengthen the nation's cybersecurity.
- The order demands minimum cybersecurity standards for government technology contractors.
- It aims to facilitate sanctions against foreign governments involved in cyberattacks, particularly targeting entities like hospitals.
- Federal agencies are required to enhance cybersecurity against potential threats from quantum computers.
- The action precedes Biden's departure from office, with hopes it will garner bipartisan support.

sources.title: President Biden’s new executive order aims to bolster national security

title: Why school cellphone bans are gaining steam in these red and blue states
summary:
- Arkansas and California governors support cellphone bans in schools, showing bipartisan agreement.
- At least eight states including California, Florida, and Indiana have enacted bans or restrictions.
- The movement is driven by concerns over mental health and classroom distractions due to cellphone use.
- Critics argue that bans hinder emergency communication for parents and students.

sources.title: Why school cellphone bans are gaining steam in these red and blue states

title: How Letterboxd went mainstream
summary:
- Letterboxd’s highest-rated film in 2020 was *Minari*, earning $15.5 million globally.
- In 2024, *Dune: Part Two* topped the charts with $714.4 million.
- Letterboxd grew from 1.8 million members in mid-2020 to over 17 million, with six million joining in the last year.
- The platform has transitioned from a niche community to mainstream popularity, expanding beyond film nerds.

sources.title: How Letterboxd went mainstream
